abstract.p: Napa Valley Wine Auctions raises record $9.5 million for local charities, nearly doubled from $5.5 million last year; Chase Bailey, retired Cisco Systems executive, paid $500,000 for six-liter bottle of 1992 Screaming Eagle Cabernet Sauvignon, a single-bottle record, and paid more that $1.7 million for five lots (M)

block.p: In California, the cost of the cultiest wines has gone way up, but the cost of your friends' admiration may be going even higher. The Napa Valley Wine Auction raised a record $9.5 million for local charities last weekend, nearly double the $5.5 million last year. One bidder, Chase Bailey, a retired Cisco Systems executive, paid $500,000 for a six-liter bottle of 1992 Screaming Eagle Cabernet Sauvignon -- a single-bottle record, according to Fritz Hatton of Christie's, the auctioneer. For five lots, Mr. Bailey paid more than $1.7 million.

In California, the cost of the cultiest wines has gone way up, but the cost of your friends' admiration may be going even higher. The Napa Valley Wine Auction raised a record $9.5 million for local charities last weekend, nearly double the $5.5 million last year. One bidder, Chase Bailey, a retired Cisco Systems executive, paid $500,000 for a six-liter bottle of 1992 Screaming Eagle Cabernet Sauvignon -- a single-bottle record, according to Fritz Hatton of Christie's, the auctioneer. For five lots, Mr. Bailey paid more than $1.7 million.

Several top bidders were techies, for whom wine country has become a favored hangout. ''There is so much money coming out of these dot-com companies,'' said Nancy Andrus, the auction chairwoman and a Pine Ridge Winery principal. ''Many people have second or third homes in Napa Valley.''
